Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a State-of-the-art High-Resolution Tomography Facility Customized for Dynamic (4D) Imaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
1531316
Wildenschild

This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program grant supports a two year project to develop a customized high resolution X-ray computed tomography (CT) imaging system with capabilities including helical scanning, region-of-interest imaging, and time resolved dynamic (4D) imaging. The developed instrument would offer the first time in an academic lab, the capability for sub-micron resolution, high fidelity computed X-ray tomographic imaging of the interiors of geologic media, outside of capabilities only now available at National Synchrotron Light Sources where beam time is extremely limited and highly competitive to gain even limited (multi-day) access. The project will involve collaboration with colleagues in the Applied Math Department at Australian National University in Canberra, Australia. The X-ray CT instrument will be managed as a shared-use laboratory, and housed in the School of Chemical, Biological and Environmental Engineering at Oregon State University.

The instrument will be employed for research and research training in studies requiring non-destructive high resolution (micron to sub-micron scale) imaging of the interiors of natural materials and the flow of fluids through porous media including studies of eruptive mechanisms of volcanoes based on observation of the fine-scale vesicular structure of basaltic lavas, studies of soil mechanics to improve mitigation strategies against landslides, liquefaction, and hydraulic collapse of soils, and studies of the fundamental behavior of fluid (including multi-phase fluids) flow in porous media to support environmental remediation efforts, geologic sequestration of CO2, geothermal energy extraction, and groundwater remediation and management. The PIs intend to develop X-ray CT image visualization modules for outreach efforts at Oregon State?s Hatfield Marine Science Center in Newport, Oregon. Studies of the behavior of fluids in the subsurface have important implications of the management of groundwater resources, remediation efforts and in characterizing subsurface hydrocarbon reservoirs. As such this grant is congruent with NSFs mission of advancing the national welfare.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this award, we have worked with collaborators at Australian National Universityto install a state-of-the-art x-ray microCT (microtomography) unit at Oregon State University (http://microct.oregonstate.edu) that produces very high quality 3D images of opaque objects, currently optimized for resolutions down to a couple of microns. It provides unique opportunities for conducting high-resolution and high-fidelity three-dimensional imaging of otherwise opaque objects..

The instrument incorporates a source that has been customized specifically for micro-CT application through a development with Hamamatsu. It combines helical scanning (allows for long vertical scans, up to 200 mm travel), autofocus alignment, novel air-bearing stages, and future development of region-of-interest imaging, and dynamic (4D) imaging. We can characterize materials from rocks to plants, to human bones, and micro-skeletons. The instrument is housed in a walk-in space, allowing for attachment of pumps, transducers, cooling and heating, etc. to the sample being inspected, allowing for conducting in-situ experiments, e.g. fluid flow experiments, while imaging. It therefore allows researchers to study form, structure, and function at the micron scale of a vast variety of materials. Users span a wide range of discplines on the OSU campus, and include a number of industry and private users as well.

The new facility supports an annual graduate level course that serves students across the OSU campus. Each year, students in the class are given the opportunity to scan a sample and use the required image processing as the subject for their term project for the class. Often these are objects they need scanned for their MS/PhD research and it allows for easy entry to the imaging and image processing needed for their research. Many subsequently return to obtain additional scanning services after the course.

The instrument also serves outreach to the broader community, e.g. the LEAFS project(https://aten-osu.github.io/LEAFSWebsite/) that serves disabled youth with an interest in STEM fields, and via community outreach, e.g. at the local farmer?s market https://twitter.com/FritzEndres/status/1119721065066799104?s=20.

Additonal example images can be found here: https://www.facebook.com/Oregon-State-University-MicroCT-Facility-166763017301498
